summary: This is an internal Department of Justice memorandum from the Southern District of New York dated August 19, 2019, requesting approval under the Hammad Memo/New York Rule of Professional Conduct 4.2 to interview a cooperating inmate witness. The document outlines the ongoing investigation into the circumstances of Jeffrey Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), focusing on staff failures, falsification of records, and potential obstruction of justice through the destruction of documents.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide while in the custody of the Bureau of Prisons at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Failure to Assign Cellmate to Epstein
events.description: MCC staff decided not to reassign a cellmate to Jeffrey Epstein, contrary to regular BOP practice and direct orders from the Warden.

events.title: Failure to Perform Overnight Checks
events.description: Correctional officers assigned to the Special Housing Unit where Epstein was housed failed to perform required overnight counts and 30-minute checks.

events.title: Shredding of Documents at MCC
events.description: An inmate reported bringing down bales of shredded paper and that he had been asked to shred documents by the BOP after-action team, suggesting potential obstruction of justice.

events.title: Continued Shredding of Documents
events.description: Continued reports of document shredding at MCC following Epstein's death.

keyFacts: The document reveals an active investigation into the circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019, focusing on potential criminal negligence and obstruction by MCC staff.
Investigators found that MCC staff failed to assign a cellmate to Epstein on August 9, contrary to orders, and that correctional officers falsified records regarding required checks on him.

The investigation uncovered potential obstruction of justice, with reports that all institutional count slips requested prior to August 10 were 'missing' and that an inmate witnessed large-scale document shredding on August 15 and 16.

The memorandum seeks approval to interview a cooperating inmate witness without his attorney present, arguing the inmate is not represented concerning his status as a witness and questions will be limited to the Epstein investigation.
